instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message:
Hello,

I have this 00165
Initial status:
-Liquid damage around <RESISTOR>R7523</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7520</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7521</RESISTOR> (Close to <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>). 
-<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground due to bad SMC. 

Repairs:
-<RESISTOR>R7523</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7520</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7521</RESISTOR>: replaced
-SMC Replaced

Current Status
-<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.42V
-<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.60V
-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
-<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>: 0V (I have 5V for 200ms)
-Green light for a moment and then orange light.

I alredy replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and PP5V still 0V. (When replacing <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> PP3V3 started to pulse, so I return the original <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message:
I forget to mention.

I tried with 2 different SMC from 00165 Boards and the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message:
Do you get one, or two pulses at L7520, when connect charger?
Check at other big coils at same moment.
Can you catch pulse at L7520 when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

Try to start in SMC bypass mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message:
After measuring what you mentioned I noticed I have 0.2ohm to ground on L7320 and L7310

-<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL>: I have 1.7v for 40mS.

Dead CPU? :/ 

Should I try Inject voltage? 

Ultrasonic cleaner?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message: Wait 10-15s after power is removed and check again resistance to ground at L7310/20.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message:
Same resistance afer 15s.

I removed L7310/20 to discard short on <TRANSISTOR>Q7311</TRANSISTOR>/21 and still have <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message:
Dead CPU then.
This board should have approx 8-15 ohm there; depending the CPU type and multimeter used.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light NO Power
threads.message: Thanks for your support, 2informaticos. I will replace the complete board.
